test_cases.query: What percentage of TB patients in the study had positive sputum culture results?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: All enrolled TB patients (100%, 33/33) had positive sputum culture results. Additionally, 93.93% (31/33) showed lung pathological symptoms by chest x-rays, and 57.58% (19/33) were T-spot positive

test_cases.query: How many participants were enrolled in the study and what were the two groups?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The study enrolled 53 participants total: 33 active tuberculosis (TB) patients and 20 healthy control (HC) subjects who were age- and sex-matched. All subjects belonged to the Han ethnic group and had no history of smoking or alcohol consumption

test_cases.query: What sequencing methods were used to analyze gut bacteria and fungi?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: For gut bacterial analysis, 16S rRNA gene sequencing was used, specifically amplifying the V3-V4 hypervariable regions with primers 338F and 806R. For gut fungi analysis, ITS2 (internal transcribed spacer region 2) was amplified with primers ITS3F and ITS4R. Both were sequenced on the MiSeq PE300 platform

test_cases.query: Which bacterial genera showed increased abundance in TB patients?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: At the genus level, Bacteroides and Prevotella showed significantly increased abundance in TB patients compared to healthy controls. Faecalibacterium also showed higher abundance in the TB group

test_cases.query: Which bacterial genera showed decreased abundance in TB patients?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The bacterial genera Blautia, Bifidobacterium, and Eubacterium_hallii_group showed significantly decreased abundance in TB patients compared to healthy subjects

test_cases.query: How did the fungal-to-bacterial species ratio change in TB patients?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The fungal-to-bacterial species ratio (ITS/16S ratio based on observed Sobs indexes) was significantly decreased in TB patients compared to healthy controls. This indicates that the equilibrium between fungi and bacteria in the gut was altered in TB patients, with a relative reduction in fungal diversity

test_cases.query: Describe the changes in alpha diversity for both bacteria and fungi in TB patients
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Both bacterial and fungal alpha diversity significantly decreased in TB patients. For bacteria, both Simpson and Chao 1 indexes were significantly lower in the TB group compared to HC. For fungi, the alpha diversity also showed decreased levels in TB patients, indicating reduced microbial richness and evenness in both kingdoms

test_cases.query: How did the trans-kingdom network differ between TB patients and healthy controls?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: The trans-kingdom network in TB patients showed dramatically reduced complexity. In healthy controls, there were 193 nodes (99 fungi/94 bacteria) with 573 edges and higher centralization and density. In TB patients, there were only 153 nodes (82 fungi/71 bacteria) with 468 edges. The bacteria-fungi interaction ratio decreased from 12.57% to 10.04%, and negative correlations between bacteria and fungi were rare in TB patients

test_cases.query: What changes occurred at the phylum level for gut bacteria in TB patients?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: At the phylum level, the abundance of Bacteroidetes was notably increased in TB patients, while Actinobacteria and Proteobacteria were significantly decreased compared to healthy subjects. Firmicutes showed decreased levels in TB patients

test_cases.query: Describe the alterations in gut mycobiota composition in TB patients
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: At the phylum level, Ascomycota was the dominant phylum and its relative abundance notably increased in TB patients (84.89% vs. 68.46% in HC). At the genus level, Saccharomyces abundance increased dramatically to 53.67% in TB patients (from 14.28% in HC). Aspergillus, Cutaneotrichosporon, and Apiotrichum were substantially reduced in TB patients compared to healthy controls

test_cases.query: How do serum levels of IFN-γ and IL-17 differ between TB patients and healthy controls?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: IFN-γ levels significantly decreased in TB patients compared to healthy controls, while IL-17 levels significantly increased in TB patients. This indicates a shift in the inflammatory cytokine profile, with reduced pro-inflammatory IFN-γ (important for controlling M.tb infection through macrophage activation) and elevated IL-17 (which can aggravate inflammation and enhance neutrophil recruitment)

test_cases.query: Explain the correlation between Bacteroides and serum cytokines in TB patients
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Bacteroides, which was enriched in TB patients, showed a negative correlation with IFN-γ (r=-0.5958) and a positive correlation with IL-17 (r=0.5997). This suggests that increased Bacteroides abundance may contribute to suppressed IFN-γ production and elevated IL-17 levels. Bacteroides produce SCFAs that may enhance TB susceptibility by suppressing B cells, CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes, ultimately reducing TB-induced IFN-γ production

test_cases.query: What was the diagnostic performance of the combined bacterial and fungal biomarker set?
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: A combined set of three bacterial genera (Bacteroides, Blautia, and Eubacterium_hallii_group) and three fungal genera (Apiotrichum, Penicillium, and Saccharomyces) showed remarkable diagnostic efficacy with an AUC of 0.996 (95% CI: 0.985-1.000). This was superior to using bacterial biomarkers alone (individual AUCs: 0.856, 0.821, 0.854) or fungal biomarkers alone (individual AUCs: 0.769, 0.804, 0.775)

test_cases.query: Compare the role of Blautia in healthy controls versus its impact in TB patients
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: Blautia showed raised levels in healthy controls and was positively correlated with IFN-γ (r=0.4413) and negatively correlated with IL-17 (r=-0.2742). Blautia has a strong ability to inhibit pro-inflammatory reactions by producing butyrate, which helps suppress IL-17. In TB patients, the reduced abundance of Blautia may contribute to decreased butyrate production, leading to higher IL-17 expression and reduced protective IFN-γ responses

test_cases.query: Describe how the gut-lung axis theory relates to the findings in this TB study
test_cases.ground_truth_answer: According to the gut-lung axis theory, gut microbiota plays a vital role in pulmonary infectious diseases like TB. This study demonstrated that TB patients have significant gut bacterial and fungal dysbiosis with decreased alpha diversity and altered composition. The dysbiosis correlates with altered immune cytokines (decreased IFN-γ, increased IL-17), suggesting that intestinal microbial changes can influence immune responses in the lungs. The altered gut microbiome may affect TB susceptibility and pathogenesis through modulation of systemic immunity

mcq_questions.question: What percentage of TB patients showed lung pathological symptoms by chest x-rays?
mcq_questions.explanation: 93.93% (31/33) of TB patients showed lung pathological symptoms by chest x-rays, including infiltrate, cavitary lesions, and miliary patterns. 100% had positive sputum culture, 57.58% were T-spot positive, and 51.51% suffered from cough

mcq_questions.question: Which sequencing platform was used for both bacterial 16S rRNA and fungal ITS analysis?
mcq_questions.explanation: Both the bacterial 16S rRNA amplicons and fungal ITS2 amplicons were sequenced on the MiSeq PE300 platform (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA) according to standard protocols

mcq_questions.question: What was the average number of bacterial ASVs (Amplicon Sequence Variants) per sample in TB patients?
mcq_questions.explanation: An average of 207 ASVs per sample were identified in TB patients for bacteria, compared to 153 ASVs in the healthy control group. For fungi, TB patients had an average of 44 ASVs compared to 110 in healthy controls

mcq_questions.question: In the trans-kingdom network of healthy controls, what was the ratio of fungi to bacteria nodes?
mcq_questions.explanation: In the healthy control group, there were 193 total nodes with 99 fungi and 94 bacteria, giving a fungi-to-bacteria ratio of 1.05. In TB patients, this decreased to 153 nodes with a ratio of 1.15 (82 fungi/71 bacteria), but with reduced network complexity

mcq_questions.question: What percentage of Ascomycota was found in TB patients versus healthy controls?
mcq_questions.explanation: Ascomycota was the dominant fungal phylum, and its relative abundance was notably increased in TB patients at 84.89% compared to 68.46% in healthy controls, showing a significant shift in fungal composition

mcq_questions.question: What was the AUC (Area Under the Curve) for the combined bacterial and fungal biomarker set in diagnosing TB?
mcq_questions.explanation: The combination set of 6 genera (3 bacterial: Bacteroides, Blautia, Eubacterium_hallii_group; and 3 fungal: Apiotrichum, Penicillium, Saccharomyces) achieved an AUC of 0.996 (95% CI: 0.985-1.000), demonstrating excellent diagnostic capacity

mcq_questions.question: Which metabolic pathway showed significantly increased levels in TB patients based on bacterial functional prediction?
mcq_questions.explanation: Using PICRUSt2 for functional prediction, glycan biosynthesis and metabolism pathways were significantly increased in TB patients. Bacteroides were positively correlated with this pathway and with transport and catabolism pathways

mcq_questions.question: According to the study, what is the primary mechanism by which Bacteroides may enhance TB susceptibility?
options: A) Direct infection of lung tissue
B) Production of toxins that damage intestinal barrier
C) Production of SCFAs that suppress immune cells and reduce IFN-γ
D) Competition with beneficial bacteria for nutrients
mcq_questions.explanation: Bacteroides produce higher quantities of short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) in the gut, which may enhance TB susceptibility by suppressing B cells, CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes, ultimately reducing the production of TB-induced IFN-γ, which is crucial for controlling M.tb infection

mcq_questions.question: What is the relationship between IL-17 levels and TB pathology according to the study?
options: A) Higher IL-17 protects against TB by activating macrophages
B) IL-17 has no significant role in TB pathogenesis
C) Excessive IL-17 aggravates inflammation, enhances neutrophil recruitment, and contributes to tissue damage and granuloma formation
D) IL-17 directly kills Mycobacterium tuberculosis
mcq_questions.explanation: IL-17 was significantly elevated in TB patients and is important for granuloma formation. However, excessive IL-17 expression can aggravate inflammation, enhance neutrophil recruitment and tissue damage. When Th17 cells produce excessive IL-17, neutrophils cluster to create tuberculosis pathological nodules

mcq_questions.question: Which statement best describes the trans-kingdom interaction changes in TB patients?
options: A) Increased positive correlations between bacteria and fungi with higher network complexity
B) No significant changes in bacterial-fungal interactions
C) Decreased network complexity, reduced bacteria-fungi interactions, and rare negative correlations
D) Complete absence of any bacterial-fungal interactions
mcq_questions.explanation: TB patients showed dramatically decreased network centralization and density. The bacteria-fungi interaction ratio decreased from 12.57% (HC) to 10.04% (TB). The fungi-fungi interaction ratio decreased from 54.97% to 38.89%. Notably, negative correlations between bacteria and fungi were rare in TB patients, indicating reduced trans-kingdom interactions and altered microbial ecosystem equilibrium
